title: Ms. Williams Interview
description:
Interviewer: Stephen Criswell, Chris Judge
Interviewee: Ms. Williams
Transcriber: Jillian Weber

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You’re a member of the Beaver Creek tribe?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Tell us a little bit about where you’re from.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Where I’m from?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well I’m born and raised around—between Neeses and north Livingston. I was born off Livingston.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Livingston, okay. How far is Livingston from here?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Oh, pretty good piece.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So you grew up there. Tell us a little bit about growing up in this area. What was it like?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, it was rough. Had to work hard.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: What’d you do?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Chopped, picked cotton, such as that and put up peanuts on poles.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You did what?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Put up peanuts—put them on a pole. And around—

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, okay. So peanuts and cotton.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Cotton seed, we put it in a bag and emptied it out on the street, at the end of the roads.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How old were you when you started?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I could pick 100 pounds when I was six years old.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you get paid by the pounds?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: 100 pounds, how much was that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: In those days, when I first got picking cotton, you pick 100 pounds, you get 50 cent.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How long would it take you to pick 100 pounds?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Beg your pardon?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How long did that take?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, you’d be there most of the day. But you had to stop and eat dinner and things like that. Had to go and get you some water.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: 50 cents. 50 cents a day.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, well, that’s about what you made. That’s what you made. I did.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: When you were six you started that. You were six years old.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And how long did you pick cotton? How old were you?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Oh mercy, I picked cotton for many years.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: About forty years ago I started, working out of Pop’s mill in Springfield.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Springfield. So, did you go to school around here?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I went to school a little bit in Four Pines and I went a little bit in Neeses and Magnolia was a country school back over in town.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Four Pines was the Indian school?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, [inaudible].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: When you went there, about how many students were there then?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Oh, I expect there was 100.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How many teachers?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Two.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Two?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Was there all the kids in one room or did they divide them up?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Two rooms.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Two rooms. Was that divided by age?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: What’d you learn there? You remember?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, I learned a little bit [laughter].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Is that the first school you went to?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And were the students there mostly from this area, Neeses?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, and that area in there.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Well, to go back to what you were talking about, the grave cemetery plots with the shells on them. Tell us a little bit about that if you’ve seen them.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, we don’t have none in our cemetery, but I’ve seen them in other cemeteries.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Just with the shells on the cement?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Somebody said cement but all I ever saw was just the dirt.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Just right on the ground?

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Just circling the grave itself?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods]

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: You think that’s an Indian tradition?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I think so.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: When you say not ours do you mean Beaver Creek or do you mean a specific church?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Uh, I went to Mt. Beulah – I was born and raised in Mt. Beulah church. Mt. Beulah Pentecostal Holiness church on (highway) 389.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And that’s not something they do there?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Where do they get the seashells?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Get those seashells? Down on the beach.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, the beach, river.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Though I have got a few on the beach myself.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: The spiral ones, the spiral are conchs or whelks right? More of a spiral than a flat?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, yeah I believe so.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So tell us a little more about growing up. You worked and you worked a lot and you worked hard.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: There were some times when you didn’t work?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Beg you?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You had some free time, though? What’d you do in your free time?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I had a playhouse and played in it some.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You did what?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I had a play house and played in it some.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh okay. What else?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I cleaned the yards.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You were talking about fishing and hunting and that sort of thing.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, I fished. I fished.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you fish with a rod or cane?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Cane.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Cane. Cane pole. What’d you catch?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I caught me a big old bass one time [spreads her arms to show the size of the fish].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Really? With a cane pole?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: That was at a pond now. The man give me permission to fish in that pond.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: What’d you use for bait?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Worms. Big worms.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: I didn’t think a bass would bite something unless—did you move it or just drop it in the water and it went after it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Drop it in the water and that bass had it!

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How much did it weigh?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I think it said three pounds and something.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, that’s a good size. What’d you do with it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: They cooked it and eat ‘em while I was in bed.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You didn’t get any of it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I don’t believe I got a bit of it.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Who cooked it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: My momma and daddy.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Your momma and daddy cooked it.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, I’m gonna tell you, used to be some of my momma’s brothers would come to our house to play cards. They done eat that fish.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So your momma’s brothers helped themselves?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: That’s a shame. That’s a shame.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: So they didn’t lose the fish in the card game. They ate it.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, that’s why they had it.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Gotcha.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How do you cook a bass like that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Just like you do any other kind of fish.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Fry it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, yeah. In a pan of grease [chuckling].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So what’d you eat growing up? What’d you usually have?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Oh lord have mercy. Oh well, it was rough now. I’ll admit it was.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: See, I’m 90 years old. I turned 90 years old the third day of July.

text.speaker: Everybody
text.text_bit: Congratulations. Happy birthday.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So you came up in hard times?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yes I did. Yes I did. Now my daddy could make syrup out of cane juice.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: And they would give him so much syrup, so we had some syrup then. Eat syrup and bread. We put fatback grease on it.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So white bread or corn bread or—?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: White bread.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: White bread. So where’d he get the cane syrup?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: People would grow cane and get my daddy to make them syrup.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, make it for them?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How’d he make it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: He had a big old family and you’d have a place to operate that stuff. People had syrup mills around.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: They’d cook it outside?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm. Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: It would be pressed or strained or something?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yes sir, yes sir. Everybody had a mule [inaudible] but when I’m coming along there was a mule that pulled that uh— [makes circular gestures with hands].

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Pull around in a circle.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, go around in a circle to get that juice out of that cane.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Okay. Now we were talking to Mr. Chavis about all of—he and his brothers sisters being born at home and the doctors would come to visit.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So when you were growing up, if somebody got sick would the doctor come to the house?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yes, they was. Doctor out of the North named Dr. James A. Ford.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: He come down to the house several times. And Doctor Connor would come down.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: How big was your family?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: There was five of us children.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Five children. So was there any time when you got sick that you’d go to the doctor? Or was there home remedies? Things like that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, I’ll tell you. I never went to the doctor much. He come down some.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: If you got something small like a bee sting—?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t go to the doctor for that. We’d do something at the house.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Remember what you had?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, I don’t remember now. That was a good many year ago.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [laughing]. I forget. I forget now.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Ms. Williams, did you always know you were an Indian?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, I certainly didn’t.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: When did you find out?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Ain’t been too many year ago.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: How’d you find out?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: With this ordeal here, I think.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Sorry, what was that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Messing with this ordeal here.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Oh, messing with this ordeal here [laughing]. She’s waving her hand at Louie’s office if anybody wants to know.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Louie’s office. So they told you you were Indian? What do you think about that? I mean, you grew up not knowing you were Indian.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: That’s right.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: But you went to the Indian school.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, there was other people there that was not Indian, in that school.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And so when you recently found out—

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I didn’t know about it when I was going to school.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: But now, a few years ago.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So what do you think about that? Is that important to you?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Whatever the Lord made me.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah. What about for your family? Have children?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [shakes head] I’ve never been married.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Smart move [laughter].

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: It’s just less complicated.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Well that’s what I meant. Okay, you’ve never been married.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: You said your father worked in a mill in Springfield.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, not my father, but me.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Oh you did. What kind of mill was it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Meat boxes.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Meat boxes?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah. Yeah, to ship things in.

text.speaker: [Older woman off-camera]
text.text_bit: Crates and boxes [inaudible].

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Makes crates, okay. What was your job there?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I was a cleat layer and one of the best to have, in fact!

text.speaker: [Older woman off-camera]
text.text_bit: Cleat layer, you know what a cleat is?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah, what is that?

text.speaker: [Older woman off-camera]
text.text_bit: [inaudible]

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: So you used the wires that held the box together? That was your job?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I put them wooden sticks in there.

text.speaker: [Older woman off-camera]
text.text_bit: [inaudible]

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: How long did you work there?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Seventeen, eighteen years.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Okay.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: There a lot of folks from this area that worked there?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [Nods].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: When you were working there were there already folks from around here working there or were you one of the first to work?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, they were there.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: They’d been working there. You know when they started this mill?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Round about? When did they start the mill?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I’d say about forty years ago.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: So they would mill the wood there? Bring in the logs and mill them there or was the lumber all brought there?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: They cut the logs and then brought them down there [inaudible].

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: What else would you like to tell us about late in life learning that you’re Indian? What does that mean?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I didn’t know my nationality until a lot of years. Well [inaudible].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So, it wasn’t until later in life that you knew you were Beaver Creek.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Real, real late.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Very late. Recently.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: But your mother and father, you think they were Indian?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, my daddy wasn’t.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Your daddy wasn’t. But your momma was?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods yes].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did she ever talk about that? Mention it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods no].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: That’s something you just know from remembering what she looked like.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods yes].

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Where was your daddy from?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Oh, around, about. Not far.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: They were kin. You know, everybody knows everybody.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Very funny. What about your brothers—you had brothers and sisters? Five of them?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did they—have any of them known they were Indian?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, no, I don’t think so.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Are they still with us?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods no]

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You’re the last of the family?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [nods yes]

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Well thanks for staying and very much for helping us.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I’m sorry I couldn’t do no better.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, you did just fine. Oh let me ask you. I always ask this question. You said you picked cotton, or maybe picked cotton.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you have a farm in your family?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, we farmed.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you grow vegetables?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Okay, did you grow potatoes or sweet potatoes?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Alright. When you—did you ever bank potatoes?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Okay, explain that to me. Tell me about that.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Well, we had plowed the potatoes and we tried to get them in the ground, in the banks we made for them, before the frost get the potatoes.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, okay.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: We put them in banks and well, we ate in the winter.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And the bank, did you dig out—you dug out a hole?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm. And we had to put like this [makes pyramid with hands] and put that dirt on them.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you put anything in there with them?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um, straw.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Pine straw?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Pine straw.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Then you put them on top of the pine straw and then you bury them.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t bury them.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You just leave them in the hole.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And why do they keep? Why don’t they rot? Or why don’t they grow?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: [laughing] I don’t know but they didn’t.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: What did you build over it? Was it like a cover?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Was that made of wood?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No. Dirt. Wood to start with and then put dirt on that wood.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Ah.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: So it’s kind of sealed off from the outside moisture. They stay kind of dry and warm. It kind of keeps—

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And then in the winter you just go out and get what you need.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you keep anything else like that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Unh-uh.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: No, just potatoes.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: What about hogs?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, had hogs. Had cows.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Did you ever cure, soft cure the hogs?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So, your family did that?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm. When I was a kid; a small kid, five or six years old.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So, they slaughtered, they killed the hog.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yep.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: And then—would they make country ham? Make ham out of the—

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Okay, what’d they do with the rest of it?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: We’d eat it.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah, you’d eat it right then or would you make—?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No, we kept it a while.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah, you make sausage?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yep, yep, liver pudding.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Oh, okay. Is that a Neeses liver pudding? Or is that Neeses—

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So, did you make the piggy hash?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I don’t know what we did. I can’t think right now.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: You eat a lot of rice up this way.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Um-hm.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Down toward the coast you get the barbeque hash rice and they’ll make it with the ears and snouts, whatever you could find?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yeah, like we used to.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Put everything in a big pot.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: [to CJ] Any other food related questions?

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Since we’re talking about food, do you know any folks around here—and I’m sure they’ve passed on—but any folks around here who made their own liquor?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Yes, they did [laughing].

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Let the record reflect the smile.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: So, you make it with corn or did they make it—?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I’ll tell you what a man done. We got what we call a family cemetery. It’s called the Chavis Cemetery in the Cedar Creek Cemetery.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: It’s not far from Mt. Beulah Pentecostal Holiness Church. Some of the neighbors round there, it’s said, made liquor. Now I saw where some wood had been burned.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Pieces like that [gestures]. People come rushing and told me what they done. Made liquor in that cemetery.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Back in that cemetery? Wow.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Well did the police give them, remember if the police gave them any trouble?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: I don’t know. See, I don’t live down in there anymore. See, I live a long walk east of there now.

text.speaker: CJ
text.text_bit: Most people probably wouldn’t go into a graveyard at night, right?

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: That’s right.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Yeah, it’d be easy to scare them away.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: [SC talking quietly off-camera]

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: Alright, well thank you very much for talking with us.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: What little bit I know to tell.

text.speaker: SC
text.text_bit: I appreciate it. And congratulations again on your recent birthday.

text.speaker: MW
text.text_bit: Thank you.
